title: 108_s2205
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that Ukraine allows its citizens the right to emigrate with minimal taxes, complies with freedom of emigration requirements, and is committed to democratic institutions and human rights as a member of OSCE. Ukraine has made progress in meeting international commitments and standards in its recent Parliamentary elections, but significant shortcomings remain, including issues with the implementation of election laws, interference by public authorities, and allegations of intimidation against opposition figures. Additionally, as an OSCE participating state, Ukraine is committed to addressing issues related to national and religious minorities and ensuring equality for all. Ukraine has also enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on identity. Ukraine has enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on identity, including anti-Semitism, and is committed to ensuring freedom of religion and combating racial and ethnic intolerance. The country is also working with US NGOs to combat ethnic and religious intolerance, continuing the restitution of religious properties confiscated from minorities during the Soviet era, and developing a legislative framework for this process. Ukraine is progressing towards joining the World Trade Organization, addressing issues such as access for US agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, and customs reform. The country has also implemented protections for labor rights in line with international standards. Ukraine has enacted protections for labor rights and committed to respecting freedom of the press as a member of the OSCE. The country aims for European integration, positive relations with neighbors, and cooperation in peacekeeping operations with the United States. The President may determine that Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 should no longer apply to Ukraine and extend permanent normal trade relations treatment to the country's products. Upon this extension, chapter 1 of Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 will cease to apply to Ukraine. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill its commitments to the OSCE, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination and violence, expanding property restitution, and respecting media freedoms. They also support Ukraine in improving in various areas and making progress in enacting and enforcing protection measures. The Congress supports Ukraine in various areas such as improving intellectual property rights, resolving trade disputes, and monitoring human rights and media freedoms. They also provide assistance to NGOs involved in human rights activities and aim to establish annual discussions on these issues. The Congress supports Ukraine in various areas such as intellectual property rights, trade disputes, human rights, and media freedoms. They also provide assistance to NGOs involved in human rights activities and aim to establish annual discussions on these issues. Additionally, reporting requirements under the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 will continue to assess specific issues, and the bilateral trade agreement between the US and Ukraine remains in force, granting the US rights to use safeguard rules in response to import surges. Congressional oversight over WTO accession negotiations is also emphasized. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A report detailing the agreement must be transmitted within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced within 30 days, it will be considered. In accordance with the subsection, a resolution of disapproval regarding the US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession must be a joint resolution of Congress. The resolution must state that the agreement does not adequately serve US interests and follow specific procedures for introduction and referral in the House of Representatives. In the House, a resolution may be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and Rules, and cannot be amended. In the Senate, a resolution may be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Finance, and may not be amended. Committee discharge and floor consideration follow specific procedures. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions regarding committee discharge and floor consideration apply to a resolution of disapproval to the same extent as resolutions under the Act. The rules of the House and Senate regarding resolutions are part of each House's rules and can be changed by that House.
